title: SHO energy - rock location in tunnel through moon

content.question: A small rock moves vertically inside a tunnel through a spherical moon that has a uniform density and no atmosphere, as shown in the figure. Inside the tunnel the gravitational force on the rock is proportional to its distance from the moon’s center, and the rock undergoes simple harmonic motion after being released from rest at the moon’s surface. The rock’s kinetic energy is <math alttext="K sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math> when it is passing through the center of the moon. When the rock’s kinetic energy is <math alttext="two thirds K sub C" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mfrac><mn>2</mn><mn>3</mn></mfrac><msub><mi>K</mi><mtext>C</mtext></msub></math>, is the rock closer to the surface or closer to the center of the moon? What evidence supports the claim?

choices.label: It is closer to the surface. The gravitational force on the rock is a maximum at the surface.
It is closer to the surface. The potential energy of the rock-moon system is proportional to the square of the rock’s distance from the center.
It is closer to the center. The kinetic energy of the rock is more than half of the total mechanical energy of the rock-moon system.
It is closer to the center. The gravitational force on the rock is inversely proportional to the square of the distance from the center.

content.answer: It is closer to the surface. The potential energy of the rock-moon system is proportional to the square of the rock’s distance from the center.

skill.text: 3.C: Justify or support a claim using evidence from experimental data, physical representations, or physical principles or laws.
